text: AN ANGLE establishing the race track, Ruidoso Downs (pronounced Ree-oh-do-so), set among the beautiful mounta of New Mexico's Lincoln National Forest, as a white Chrys turns in with a stream of cars moving toward the parking area. AN ANGLE through the open driver-side window of the Chrys at LILLY DILLON, 39 but looking younger, beautiful but co and watchful. WIDE SHOT, track in b.g. as Lilly parks the Chrysler, get out, locks the car. As she walks toward the track, WIPE RIGHT, as SCENE TWO WIPES IN from the left. SCENE ONE CAM FOLLOWS Lilly as she walks across the large parking area. SPLIT SCREEN.

Downtown Los Angeles, near the courts and the business section. ROY DILLON, 25, handsome and charming but self indulgent, parks his orange Honda convertible, gets out, picks up a large ledger book from the back seat, goes aro to open the trunk. AN ANGLE on the trunk, establishing the tools of the salesman's trade: catalogs, samples, ledgers full of manu and product sheets. Roy adds the ledger from the back sea shuts the trunk, walks away.

Roy walks around the corner near a bar/restaurant. As he approaches it, WIPE LEFT, the two half-width scenes contracting to one-third each as SCENE THREE WIPES IN fro the right. SCENE ONE: Lilly approaches the track's entrance doors. SCENE TWO: Roy approaches the bar.

A baby blue Cadillac parks in front of a jeweler. AN ANGLE on the driver's door as MYRA LANGTRY, 36, beauti in an impersonal calculating way, gets out, carrying a sm jewelry care, and locks the car. At first glance, Myra lo rather like Lilly. (Myra always wears large dangly earrin and usually wears big-lensed dark sunglasses.)
SCENE ONE: Lilly enters the track. SCENE TWO: Roy enters the bar. SCENE THREE: Myra enters the jeweler's. WIPE RIGHT AND LEFT, as SCENE TWO takes FULL SCREEN.

AN ANGLE on a hurried bartender in a full bar, crowded wi NOISY lunchtime crowd. In b.g., Roy slithers his way to t bar, waving a bill in the air to attract the bartender's attention. AN ANGLE on Roy as the bartender comes to him. Roy puts t bill on the bar, holding it down with one finger, as he SHOUTS his order. The bartender looks down. BARTENDER'S POV: Roy's finger holds down a twenty dollar bill. AN ANGLE steep over Roy's shoulder, the twenty visible, a the bartender hurries away to get the drink. Roy's hand m a fist, swallowing the twenty, opens, pushing a ten out o the bar, holding it there with one finger. AN ANGLE on the bartender returning with a draft beer, nodding to other ORDERS shouted to him along the way, put the beer down, grabbing the bill without looking at it, hurrying away. AN ANGLE on Roy, content, smiling, sipping his beer. AN ANGLE on the bartender, hurrying by, slapping Roy's ch down, moving on, Roy nodding acknowledgement, reaching ou CU, the change, a ten dollar bill on top. Roy's hand clos over it.
WIDE SHOT, the tote board at the track, showing the shift odds on the horses for the next race, the amounts bet. CLOSE SHOT, number 3. Not much bet, odds 70-1.

AN ANGLE on Lilly, frowning at the tote board. She carrie large heavy shoulder-bag, which she opens, looking in it though it were a file drawer. AN ANGLE on Lilly studying the contents of her bag, the t beyond her, the mountains visible out beyond the track wa Lilly moves. AN ANGLE on a high-dollar betting window, as Lilly approaches, taking bank-banded wads of bills from her bag
A change of numbers sweeps across the board.

Lilly moves away from the betting window, tucking betting tickets into her bag. ECU, Lilly's bag, compartmented, with stacks of money, sm envelopes and notes on notepaper in each compartment. Lil carefully files the betting slips. AN ANGLE on Lilly looking out at the tote board.
CU, number 3. Odds 32-1.
AN ANGLE on Lilly, not satisfied. She turns and goes back AN ANGLE at the betting window as Lilly arrives and makes more bets.
CU, number 3. Odds 32-1. CROWD NOISE INCREASES. The numbe shift: odds 26-1.
And they're off!

Very quiet, stately; abrupt contrast with the track. A sl ticking clock. Myra sits in the client's chair, while at the desk sits t JEWELER, a pleasant but overweight man of 40, who studies jeweled bracelet through a loupe. He sighs, drops the lou shakes his head regretfully.
Mrs. Langtry, I'm sorry.
Why? What's wrong?
(personal emotion mixed in) You are a valued customer, as you know.
But what's wrong?
I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.
What is?
(holding up bracelet) This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.
But they must be! They cut glass!
(wry) Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?

An expensive hotel room, with a sunstruck day beyond the windows. Myra, naked, a few years younger, sits cross-leg on the bed and laughs at COLE "FARMER" LANGLEY, 55, strin bodied, who stands naked, his back to us, hands on hips, presenting himself to Myra. She reaches forward, hand hid by his body as she lifts something that was hanging on something at the front of him. She brings back the bracel looks at it, is delighted, puts it on, and then leans for again toward the unmoving Cole, her head hidden by his bo
It was a gift. It isn't worth anything at all?
(warm, encouraging) Why, of course it is. I can offer you -- well, five hundred dollars.
Myra expected -- and needed -- a lot more. She's worried, tense, but stuck. She nods.
All right.
(rising) I'll get you a check.
He leaves the room. Myra grimaces, in almost physical pai

Another crowded lunchtime bar. A big beefy BARTENDER move quickly, carrying a draft beer. AN ANGLE on Roy, in position, finger holding bill down, a the bartender arrives, puts down the beer, reaches for th bill, stops, stares at the bill. TWO SHOT, the bartender and Roy, as the bartender gives R very cold look. He knows, and Roy knows he knows. Roy tri an innocent smile, which doesn't work. Roy moves. CU, the ten dollar bill, as Roy grabs it, but the bartend simultaneously grabs Roy's wrist. AN ANGLE on Roy and the bartender as Roy tries to pull aw and the bartender holds him with his left hand while reac under the bar with his right. He comes up with a sawed-of baseball bat. Roy, seeing it, throws his free arm up to protect his head, but the bartender pushes the blunt end the bat straight across the bar at a downward angle and h into Roy's solar plexus, driving the air out of him and propelling him back away from the bar, leaving the ten. T nearest CUSTOMERS on both sides become aware that somethi happened, but nothing follows and they're already involve conversations. The bartender scoops up the ten as he puts bat away under the bar. AN ANGLE on Roy, arms folded across his torso, staring in shock toward the bar, where the space he filled has alrea been closed in by other bodies. Nearly retching, he stumb toward the door.

AN ANGLE on four PEOPLE at a table, CHEERING a race, switching to disgust and despair when they lose, moving a from the table, leaving their betting tickets behind. Lil passes by, smoothly and casually scoops up the tickets, m on along a row of tables, and there finding more tickets.
Myra sits as before. The jeweler enters with a check, whi he hands her. She looks up at him, making no move to leav
I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.
It's not your fault.
You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...
I have only one thing now. Are you interested?
Well, I'd have to see it, of course.
You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.
The jeweler is puzzled, then startled.
I see.
He turns away, goes behind his desk, sits down, looks at Myra.

You know something, Mrs. Langtry? A bracelet like that very rarely happens. A fine setting and workmanship usually mean precious stones. It always hurts me when I find they're not. I always hope --  (faint sad friendly smile) -- I'm mistaken.
Myra likes him better now, even though he hasn't solved h problem. She rises.
Thank you. For everything you felt you could do.

Roy has been throwing up but is finished now. He's sprawl like a shot deer across the hood of his Honda, still clutching his stomach. A police car stops, the passenger gets out. He's suspicious at first.
Sir? Everything all right?
The sight of the uniform forces Roy into gear. He straightens, smiling through his pain.
Getting better. A bad shrimp, I think.
The con's suspicion changes to concern.
Want us to take you to a doctor?
No no, I'm fine now, thanks, anyway. Still got a lot of clients to see.
Take it easy, now.
Oh, I will.

Late afternoon. AN ANGLE on the parking area, where almos all the cars are gone and the few remaining are widely separated. The white Chrysler is one of these. Lilly walk it from the track entrance. AN ANGLE on the Chrysler as Lilly opens the trunk, puts h bag inside. CLOSE UP, Lilly and the trunk. She takes betting tickets her bag, sorts them, files them in envelopes in different compartments, puts some to one side, then sorts through t separated tickets, throwing some away, keeping some. She takes money from the bag, puts tickets in, closes the bag with the money on the trunk floor. Reaching farther in, s lifts the pad deep inside the trunk, lifts the metal floo panel, and reveals a cache mostly filled with money. She today's skim, puts everything away, puts the bag back on shoulder, closes the trunk.
A shabby apartment hotel on Wilshire. An exterior hall balcony on each floor has the entrance doors to the front apartments. Roy's Honda makes the turn and enters the basement garage.
Modest but clean. The owner, SIMMS, a sloppy garrulous ol bore, talks with a potential RENTER.

Put it this way, now. Say I rent to a woman, well, she has to have a room with a bath. I insist on it, because otherwise she's got the hall bath tied up all the time, washing her goddamn hair and her clothes and everything she can think of.
In b.g., Roy, still in pain, comes out of the elevator, w to Simms, who waves back without pausing in his monologue and crosses to the mailboxes.

Now, your minimum for a room with bath is three hundred a month, just for a place to sleep and no cooking allowed. And just how many of these tootsies make that kind of money and have to eat in restaurants and buy clothes and --
Roy, carrying his junk mail and pretending not to be in p crosses to Simms.
Mr. Simms.
(fawning) Why yes, Mr. Dillon. Here's a potential new neighbor, looking at--
(uninterested) Uh-huh. Mrs. Langtry may drop by.
Simms doesn't like Mrs. Langtry, but can't say so.
I'll send her right up.
Roy goes back to the elevator. Simms continues his monolo

I had my first hotel thirty-seven years ago in Wichita Falls, Texas, and that's where I began to learn about women. They just don't make the money, you see, not regular they don't, and there's only one way they can get it.
Roy enters the elevator.

Now, that Mr. Dillon there, that's the fine type of person I have in mind for here. Like yourself, I have no doubt. He's a salesman, regular as clockwork, has a suite here. Fine man. Now, about these women. At first, you know, they just go out and do it now and then, just enough to make ends meet. But pretty soon they got that bank open twenty-four hours a day, and then you've got trouble. Hookers and hotellin' just don't mix. You'd think the cops'd be too busy catching real criminals, not snooping around after working girls, but that's the way the gravy stains, as the saying is, and I don't fight it. An ounce of prevention is my motto.
Myra enters from the front, looks across at Simms, points upward. Simms calls to her.
Oh, yes, Mrs. Langtry, he's up there, he's expecting you.
Myra crosses to the elevator. Simms speaks more softly.
If you keep out the women in the first place, see, you keep out the hookers, and then you keep out the cops, and that's how you have a clean place.
AN ANGLE along the balcony, with Roy's apartment door in and Los Angeles in b.g. Myra crosses to the door, opens i with her key, enters.
A small crowded old-fashioned bathroom. Roy, shirt open a trousers pushed down almost to his crotch, looks in the mirror at purplish greenish bruises on his stomach. He touches his stomach, winces.
Roy?
He looks at the door, then grins at his reflection.
Your medicine is here.
He leaves the bathroom.

Hotel furniture, shabby and anonymous. On the walls, contrasting with everything else, are two crying-clown pictures on black velvet, mounted in big boxy frames. Myr stands in the middle of the room, and Roy enters, shirt a trousers still disarranged.
(amused by clothing) Well, well. In a real hurry, are we?
Always, for you, baby.
He reaches for her, but she playfully holds him off.
You aren't taking me for granted, are you?
Taking you for granite?
He grins, as his fingertip prods her breast.
That isn't granite. If that fell on me, it wouldn't hurt at all.
(playing along) Are you sure?
(pulling her close) Let's find out.
Lilly's white Chrysler is parked next to an open-air phon Traffic whizzes by. Lilly talks on the phone, with pen an notebook at the ready. The racetrack is visible in the b.
I'm done here. Do I come back to Baltimore?

It could be an expensive, if gaudy, lawyer's office. Baltimore harbor is visible past the windows. IRV, the accountant, sits at a desk covered -- but neatly covered with ledgers, computer printouts, etc. He speaks on the phone.
Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.
Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.
Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.
(fatalistic) I know.
Take two, three days. Call when you get there.
Maybe I'll swing around Los Ang gleez on the way.
This is Lilly making the best of the situation. She liste bit more, GRUNTS a farewell, hangs up, moves to her car.
Again, anonymous hotel furniture. Roy and Myra naked in b he on his back, she straddling him, both moving gently. H half feeling pleasure, half unconscious.
Roy?
Mm?
Look at me.
Oh, I am, baby, believe me.
Roy? It this all we have?
All? It ain't bad.
No more than this?
He tries to concentrate on her.
What are you talking abut, Myra? Marriage?
I didn't say that. You aren't marriage material.
He keeps watching her, ironic, hips moving. Looking for a distraction, she notices the bruise on his stomach.
What's that?
She touches it; he flinches back, in real pain.
Ow! Hey, what are you trying to do, throw me off my game?
(laughing) No, baby. Come to Mama.
She folds forward onto him. He puts his arms around her. rock together slowly.
The same mountains in b.g. as at the track. Lilly carries small bags from her motel room, puts them on the back sea the Cadillac, gets behind the wheel, drives away.
Myra, dressed, primps at the mirror, surveys herself critically, is reasonably satisfied, leaves.
Roy lies supine on the bed, semi-conscious, half-covered sheet. Myra, casual, not noticing his condition, leans he head in through the doorway.
Wore you out, did I? It's a good woman you can't keep down, baby.
He moves fitfully, CROAKS an attempt at speech.
Have a good sleep, baby. Call you tomorrow.
He sits up, trying to grin and be easy.
Wait'll next year.

AN ANGLE across Roy's profile, with open bedroom door bey him. Through it, the living room and outer door can be se Myra crosses the living room, opens the door. Bright sunl pours in, emphasizing the sweat on his face. She closes t door, and he gives up trying to smile. Gingerly, he touch his bruised stomach, winces.
Damn that guy.

He's going to get out of bed, but movement creates pain. sits back against the headboard, looks around, reaches painfully to the bedside table drawer, takes a quarter fr it, studies the quarter, feels it with fingertips, places on the back of his left hand, slowly moves the soft pads his right palm over it, then turns the quarter over and repeats. Then he takes the quarter in his right hand, fli it, slaps it down onto the back of his left hand, SPEAKS simultaneously with the hands coming together.
Smack.
He looks away, right hand moving minimally on left hand.
Heads.
He lifts the right hand, nods, then flips the coin again, looks away, moves the right hand slightly.
Heads.
Again he's right. Again he repeats.
Tails.

He's about to repeat when a wave of weakness comes over h He sits back, gasping, but won't acknowledge the problem. He forces himself to flip the coin, misses catching it, f it on the blanket, flips it again, slaps it onto the back the other hand, looks away.
Tails.
Right again. He prepares to flip the coin, but then his h sags onto the covers, his chin drops, his eyes glaze.
(whispered) How much can I bet?

The train runs through a forest, tree shadows making a li and-dark pattern. Roy, four or five years younger, sits w a three-core-monte gang, consisting of a DEALER, a specta SHILL beside him, Roy facing the dealer, a ROPER next to On a briefcase on the dealer's lap are three cards, face An ace and two deuces. Across the aisle, alone in the sea sits MINTZ, a conman in his fifties, pretending not to wa but watching with amusement.
That's between you two. I got nothing at stake here, I'm just dealing.
What if we both guess wrong? You aren't gonna take...

The dealer turns aside, allowing himself to be distracted and the shill ARGUE nonsensically. The roper nudges Roy, reaches out and crimps the ace. Roy's doing a wide-eyed bumpkin kid; he stares at the roper in delight and amazem AN ANGLE on the shill, arguing with the dealer but lookin toward Roy and the roper, then increasing the force of hi argument. AN ANGLE across the amused Mintz at the roper whispering Roy. TWO SHOT, Roy and the roper.
We got him now! Put down that big bill you got.
(whispered) The fifty or the hundred?
The hundred! Hurry!
(doubtful) The ace is what I want?
The roper's having trouble keeping his patience.
Sure it is!

TWO SHOT, the dealer and the shill, fake-squabbling, Roy the roper seen in b.g. between their faces, Roy finally bringing out his wallet, withdrawing a bill. Relieved, th dealer and the shill cut the crap. AN ANGLE on the group as Roy puts his hundred dollar bill the briefcase.
Is that okay?
The shill pulls a messy wad of bills from his inner pocke uses most of it to cover the bet.
You're damn right that's okay.
(picks up the cards) Whoever finds the ace, wins.
ECU, the dealer's hands, shuffling the cards at lightning speed. He deals the cards out face down.
CU, Roy's sweat-covered face, eyelids fluttering.
(whispered) Dark in here.
AN ANGLE on the group. Roy squints at the cards, light an dark playing on his face.
Too dark. I just can't see.
Casually, but too quickly to be stopped, he reaches acros and plucks the shill's glasses off.
Let me borrow these, will you?
AN ANGLE across Mintz, surprised and amused, at the group b.g., in consternation as Roy puts on the glasses and loo down at the cards.
Now, that's better.
ROY'S POV: The glasses are 'readers.' Through them, a lar gray 'A' can be seen on the back of one of the non-crimpe cards. Roy's hand reaches out and flips it over. It's the of spades.
AN ANGLE across Roy toward the doorway. Roy, eyes closed, smiles in triumph, then winces in pain. Mintz partially appears, hovering beside the bed, grinning at Roy.
I didn't teach you that.
(whispered) You taught me a lot. Then I invented.
Weary bored people sit around waiting. Roy, 17, lugging a suitcase, walks through, takes a seat near Mintz, who's d card tricks for his own pleasure. Roy watches, then moves closer.
Let me see how you did that one.
Scram. Go home.
I can't. I just left home.
You're too young. You should be in school.
I am in school.
Mintz peers at him, taking an interest. Then he holds up five of spades, shows it to Roy, puts it back in the deck shuffles, shows Roy the deck.
Where's the five?
In your other hand.
Mintz grins slowly, turns his hand over with the palmed c showing.
Roy slumps, eyes closed, half-smiling, with the fever Min hovering. Roy's smile fades, his fluttering eyelids grow still, his face slack. The fever Mintz fades and disappea

AN ANGLE on a large sign indicating "Los Angeles" straigh ahead. CAMERA PANS DOWN and around 180 degrees to face th several lanes of heavy Los Angeles-bound traffic. LONG BE Hundreds of cars rush by. CAMERA PANS with Lilly's white Chrysler as it comes along in the stream. AN ANGLE through the Chrysler's left side window at Lilly driving, concentrating, biting her left thumbnail. She becomes aware that's what she's doing, shakes her head in irritation: She's trying to break herself of this habit. Ostentatiously she tucks the thumb into her fist, rests t fist on top of the steering wheel, where she can keep an on it. HIGH ANGLE on the westbound lanes. The Chrysler passes. S it's out of sight among all the other cars. LONG BEAT.

AN ANGLE across the unmoving unconscious Roy toward the doorway. The apartment door beyond the living room opens, throwing light on Roy, who doesn't react. Lilly enters, i silhouette, closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom. (Until she speaks, we can't be quite sure who this is. Wi the similarity between herself and Myra, this could be My
(hesitant) Roy?
No reaction. Lilly, getting worried, moves closer, throug the bedroom doorway.
Roy? You asleep?
His head moves slightly. He barely has strength to speak.
Myra?
She moves forward to the side of the bed, only her torso FRAME. She touches a hand to his forehead.
(startled) My God!
She turns, hurries back to the living room, looks around the phone, crosses to it, dials, SPEAKS. Roy's eyes open, frowns.
Lilly?
Lilly, hard and fast and urgent, on the phone.
Tell the doctor I work for Bobo Justus, and this is an emergency. Don't worry, he knows who Bobo is.
AN ANGLE down toward Roy, from above, he's weak but troub Eyes closed, frowning, whispering.
Go away, Lilly. Go away.
Roy's eyes close. He looks dead. SLOW FADE.

The DOCTOR, a nervous heavyset man in his fifties, a drin from the look of him, is on the phone in b.g., while Lill prowls the room, looking at everything with distaste, the stopping to frown at the box-framed clown pictures. She doesn't get it. She touches one of the pictures, trying t understand. The doctor hangs up, turns to Lilly.
(lugubrious) The ambulance is on the way, for what good it will do.
What? He's going to be all right!
Mrs. Dillon, your son was in some sort of accident. He's had an internal hemorrhage, he's bleeding to death inside.
Well, make it stop!
His blood pressure is under a hundred. I don't think he'll live to get to the hospital.
(icy, stern) You know who I work for.
He's uncomfortable, wants to dismiss that part of his lif
Yes, yes, but that's --
My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed.

The doctor stares at her in astonishment, then in belief. SOUND of ambulance siren. To break the moment, he crosses the door, opens it. Light bathes Lilly. The doctor steps across the threshold, waiting for the ambulance. He looks back at Lilly, who stares at him.
ECU, Roy, skin pallid, eyes closed and sunken, lips white SOUND of siren LOUDER. SOUND SEGUES to CHILD CRYING. CRYI FADES.

A clumsy slum hotel fifteen years ago, with a tiny lobby, DESK CLERK at a half-door in one wall. Lilly, at 24, ente from the street. This is a definite hooker, with bright maroon hair and a black-and-white miniskirt. She stops wordlessly at the desk for her key.
(handing key) Your kid's in the back here. He's crying.
Roy? He's always crying.
(sympathetic to Roy) The kids beat him up, because his home life is, uh, different.
(ironic) I like you, too.
The clerk shrugs. He doesn't like this tough broad. He tu and calls back into his office.
Roy, your mother's here.
Roy, 10, comes reluctantly out to Lilly, sniffling and rubbing his arm.
So what's your story today?
They twisted my arm.
(laughing lightly) Only one arm?
He tries not to cry, and shows her a space between his te
They knocked out my tooth!
Only one tooth?
Roy's frustrated, unhappy, having nowhere else to turn.
You always say that!
Lilly won't take him seriously, but she relents enough to stop teasing him, and to pat his head, ignoring how he flinches away.
Come on, kid, let's see if there's any food in the house.
(there's no food) Hah.
Lilly gives him a jaundiced look, walks Roy to the stairs up. The clerk, scornful but sexually interested, watches go.
ECU, Roy in a hospital bed, with more color in his face, breathing more normally. He begins to react to the sound people speaking.
No, really, you're Roy's mother? That's impossible!
Not quite. But I'm not sure who you are, Mrs... Langtry, was it?
Roy's eyes open, he looks toward the voices.
I'm Roy's friend.

WIDE SHOT, Lilly and Myra facing one another across the f of Roy's bed, in a two-bed hospital room. (The OLD MAN in other bed sleeps through the scene.) Neither woman is yet aware that Roy's awake. Lilly looks Myra up and down, wit obvious contempt.
Yes. I imagine you're lots of people's friend.
Myra moves one pace to the side, studying Lilly's face.
Oh, of course, now that I see you in the light, you're plenty old enough to be Roy's mother.
(sweet smile) Aren't we all?
(very weak, but amused) Play nice. Don't fight.
The women, startled, both move toward Roy, one on each si of the bed. THREE SHOT, Myra and Lilly both leaning over to look down Roy's sleepy face.
Darling!
Roy. You're going to be all right.
Sure I am. What made you turn up, after all these years?
I'm working down in San Diego. Just for a few weeks. (awkward laugh) Thought I'd drop in on my long-lost son.
(cold) Nice to see you. (turns to Myra) What am I doing in here?
You were bleeding inside, honey. Remember that bruise you had?
You called the doctor, huh?
(reluctant) Well, no, Roy. Your mother found you.
(tossing It away) Oh, yeah? (very casual, to Lilly) Thanks. (back to Myra) How long do they say I'm in here?
Myra's willing to fight with Lilly, but Roy's attitude to his mother makes her uncomfortable.
Roy... Your mom saved your life.
Roy turns his head, gives Lilly an ironic smile. Lilly wa holding herself in.
Yeah? Only one life?
She nods, accepting that, but then responds.
Second time I gave it to you.
Roy gives her a cold smile, then turns to Myra for the ir explanation.
I was kind of... inconvenient... for Lilly.
Lilly has nothing but contempt for Myra. To be humiliated front of Myra -- and by her son -- is the worst thing tha could happen to her. She makes as dignified an exit as sh can.
Well... You're all right now, I guess. I have to get down to the track.
(reluctant, but it's necessary) Thanks, uh, Lilly.
(awkward laugh) Don't mention it.
I guess I owe you my life.
(faint smile) You always did.
Lilly exits. Myra looks after her, curious.
"Down to the track?"
Roy will not talk about this, with anyone. His response i cold, closing the subject.
Her job.
(bright smile) I want to know everything about you.
(easy grin) You do. And once I'm out of here, I'll remind you of the best parts.
They smile flirtatiously at one another, both with their minds on other things.

Very messy, small. Myra showers. She finishes, emerges, w herself in a towel, opens the crowded messy medicine cabi removes cosmetics and other items, starts to tweeze her eyebrows. Doorbell RINGS. She looks irritated, ignores it Long doorbell RING. Exasperated, she slaps the tweezers d exits.

Another furnished apartment, this one with Myra's clothin and dishes and glasses and other junk all over it. She crosses to the door, pulls it open. The APARTMENT MAN enters; a sullen, nervous, heavyset man.
(angry, but defensive) You heard the shower, didn't you?
I don't care about that. This time, I gotta have the rent.
Myra forces herself to be more pleasant.
Joe, I thought I was gonna be all  right by now, I just need a little more --
It isn't the owner, Myra, it's my wife. She knows what's going on. This time, I gotta have the money.
Joe, you know you'll --
In gesturing, Myra "accidentally" loses the towel, then w it around herself again as the manager stares nervously a She smiles, knowing she's got him.
Joe, could we talk it over? Do you want a drink?
My wife sent me here, Myra. For the money. She's waiting.
I'll have it tonight. Nine o'clock? Ten?
(trying to be determined) This time...
We'll work something out, Joe.
She strokes his arm, smiling. He flees. She smiles till h gone, then looks worried, leans her head against the door
Roy, very comfortable in pajamas and robe, sits in a wheelchair beside the bed, with magazines lying handy on bed. Myra, irritable, paces beside him.
I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.
I just do what the doctor says, babe.
You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.
(truly astonished) Mama!
Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.
(insulted) I'll pay Lilly back, don't you worry about that.
I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.
That's just Lilly's way.
And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.
Oh, don't be stupid.
You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth.
This is so absurd, Roy doesn't know how to respond.

Lilly enters, smiling in self-confidence. A large ugly bu is on the back of her right hand.
Should my ears be burning?
(surly) They might as well.
Lilly gives her a mock-admiring look.
I heard those skirts were coming back.
Myra's not quite up to direct confrontation with Lilly. S glowers at Roy instead.
Get well soon.
(easy) Every day in every way.
I'll see you when you get home.
Myra stalks out. Acting as though Myra hadn't existed, Li puts her bag on the bed, takes mail from it.
What happened to your hand?
(casually dismissive) Just a little accident. I went by your place, picked up your mall. Just bills, I'll take care of them.
I can take care of my own bills, Lilly.
(indifferent shrug) Whatever you say. The manager says your boss called. (crooked grin) Really pulled the wool over everybody's eyes, huh?
What are you talking about? So I've got a job. So what?
Stop kidding me! Four years in a town like Los Ang-gleez, and a peanut selling job is the best you can do? You expect me to believe that?
(spreads hands; it's obvious) It's there. The boss called, you said so yourself.
And that dump you live in! Those clown pictures on the walls!
This reference alerts and worries Roy, which he tries to hide.
I like those.

You do not! Roy Dillon? Cornball clown pictures? Commission salesman? It's all a front, isn't it? You're on the grift, I know you are. You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!
(defensive) You're one to talk. Still running playback money for the mob.
That's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy, and if you --
How come?
She considers him. His expression is jaunty, daring her. gives him a somber answer.
You aren't tough enough.
He's afraid she's right. He covers the doubt with a displ of self-assurance.
Not as tough as you, huh?
(dead serious) No. And you have to be.
She holds up her burned hand, showing it to him.
You asked me about this. You really want to know what happened?
He isn't sure he does; but what choice does he have?
Up to you.
My boss is a guy named Bobo Justus, back in Baltimore. When a long shot gets too much action, I have to put money on that horse at the track, because it's the only way to get the odds down.
Sure.
The first day of the Delmar meet, there was a nag called Bluebell. I should have been on it. But that was the day after you came in here, so I stuck around to see how you were gonna be.
He would speak protest, deny, explain, but she cuts him o

AN ANGLE on the exit doors toward the parking lot. Lilly comes out, self-absorbed, then sees something ahead of he falters briefly, keeps walking, tries a very shaky smile. Driving along the highway. Lilly concentrates on traffic. Bobo heavily watches her profile, finally speaks.
Bluebell.
Lilly's eyes briefly close, her shoulders sag. Then she g back to the silent alert person she'd been. Bobo nods.
How'd you figure you were gonna get away with that?
I'm not getting away with anything, Bobo.
You're fuckin right you're not. How much did your pals cut you in for on that nag, huh? Or did they give you the same kind of screwing you gave me?
I was down on that horse, Bobo. Not as much as I should have been, but there was a lot of action on those--
Bobo taps a fingertip against the side of her head to shu her up. She shuts up.
One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?
I want to keep my teeth.

Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. (utter scorn) Motherhood.

(begging) It'll never happen again. I swear.

You're calling the shots.

(deadened with fear) No.
(doesn't matter) I'll loan you a raincoat.

A tall expensive hotel on the coast north of San Diego. CAMERA PANS with the Chrysler pulling in and stopping at entrance, then PANS UP the balconied facade.

Yes, sir.

Kaggs. Home office.

Small, crowded, efficient, with interior windows showing aisles of bins. Kaggs leads Roy in, shuts the door, gestu at the second chair as he goes behind the desk.
Take a seat.
They both sit, Roy amused and observant.

When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.
(dry) So I heard.
Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?
Just myself.

That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think?
Roy doesn't yet know he's being offered the job.
Sounds like a good Idea.
I don't know offhand what your best year's been, we can look it up. The idea is, we'll top it by fifteen percent.
Now Roy gets it. He's startled, almost scared, thinks automatically of escape.

I take care of the being-fair-to-me department. Things've gone to hell this long, they can go a little longer.
(trapped) Well...

See you in a week, Roy. I can call you Roy?

Roy's place. Roy enters from the bedroom, carrying a suitcase, which he drops on the sofa. Myra applies makeup, watching herself in her compact mirr She becomes aware of eyes, and looks around. TWO SHOT, Myra and a BUSINESSMAN, sitting across the way, grinning at her. Myra registers him. A brightly lit Hopperish place. Lilly sits alone in a boo eating a bowl of chili and reading a newspaper folded bes the bowl.
